rest.sentence: Perovskite/silicon tandem solar cells are one of the most efficient ways to improve the performance of the photovoltaic industry and should be viewed as a promising path in the photovoltaic field
The silicon photovoltaic modules have a lifespan of over 20 years, while the low device stability of perovskite solar cells  remains a significant commercialization barrier
An air gap acts as an optical spacer layer for four terminal  perovskite/silicon tandem cells, resulting in a loss of efficiency

Using polydimethylsiloxane  as an intermediate matching layer  and a clip-on design made of a PDMS-based material sandwiched between polyvinyl chloride  layers with the configuration of PVC/IML/PVC, this research not only achieved efficiency improvement of four-contact tandem solar cells but also greatly simplified disassembly of individual cells

The 4T perovskite/silicon heterojunction tandem cells with a clip-on design achieved the highest efficiency of 23.49% for the active area of 1 cm2, while the fully tandem configuration without a clip-on layer only exhibited a PCE of 22.83%
The clip-on technology has the potential to boost the current density of silicon heterojunction solar cells from 15.01 mA/cm2  up to 16.51 mA/cm2
Therefore, this state-of-the-art allows for the removal of PSCs with a shorter lifespan while adhering two photovoltaic cells together securely and effectively.
Download : Download high-res image Download : Download full-size image

Silicon photovoltaic technology has dominated the global market due to its superior performance in terms of efficiency, stability, and cost reduction compared to other types of photovoltaic cells [1,2]
On a laboratory scale, a single-junction crystalline silicon solar cell  can achieve the highest power conversion efficiency  of 26.7% [1,2]
Meanwhile, perovskite solar cells  have advanced rapidly to achieve the highest PCE, up to 25.5%, during the past decade, compared with other photovoltaic technologies

PSCs also have superior light absorption coefficient, long carrier lifetime, and tunable bandgap  by optimizing component engineering [, ], making them an excellent candidate for the next generation of photovoltaic technology
Nevertheless, the PCE for a c-Si solar cell remained lower than the theoretical efficiency limit of silicon photovoltaic technology

To overcome this obstacle, tandem solar cells, which consist of two sub-cells, are one of the most effective ways to enhance the solar cell performance and should be viewed as a promising path in the photovoltaic field

Two significant types of tandem solar cells have been developed thus far monolithically integrated two-terminal  tandem configurations, which require electrical matching between the top and bottom compartments, and mechanically stacked four-terminal  tandem configurations, which connect each cell independently without current matching [, ].
The combination of silicon and PSCs has been considered a prime candidate for the sub-cells of tandem solar cells due to their high PCE close to the theoretical limit, as mentioned previously
With the wide band gap-semitransparent perovskite and narrow band gap silicon as the top and bottom cells, the efficiency of light collection across all wavelengths is significantly enhanced

This was due to the synergistic effect of the perovskite/silicon tandem solar cell, in which the semitransparent perovskite top cell with transparent electrodes absorbs light at short wavelengths, and the silicon bottom cell harvests the long wavelength light passthrough, thereby increasing PCE
Up to this point, Al-Ashouri, A
have reported a monolithic perovskite/silicon tandem with a certified power conversion efficiency of 29% et al
Tockhorn, P., et al
have demonstrated the 2T perovskite/silicon tandem design with a nanotexture of silicon bottom cells that achieved a PCE of 29.8%
An efficiency performance of 2T perovskite/silicon tandem have recently recorded exceeding 31%
The 4T perovskite/silicon tandem solar cells with a PCE of up to 27% have been investigated by Jaysankar, M
, and Wang, Zet al
Moreover, a bifacial 4T perovskite/silicon tandem solar cells with a PCE of over 30% was exhibited by Kim S., et alet al

To pursue high 4T tandem cell efficiencies, achieving high transmission of semitransparent PSC at wavelengths longer than the cut-off wavelength of perovskite absorption would otherwise result in significant optical losses to the silicon bottom cells
This is one of the most important issues
Furthermore, in perovskite/silicon tandem devices, the transmittance of the semitransparent PSC composed of two-layer transparent electrodes must be maximized for sub-bandgap wavelengths

In addition, semitransparent perovskite top cells with non-metal transparent electrodes, indium tin oxide  [6,18,19], and aluminum-doped zinc oxide  [, ] were utilized instead of metal electrodes to reduce the reflected light loss.
The air gap was another crucial factor that required attention
When an air gap serves as an optical spacer layer between individual sub-cells, the performance of the device is diminished

To induce more light incidents on the bottom solar cell, an intermediate matching layer  must be incorporated into the design of an effective light management material for 4T perovskite/silicon tandem cells
et alYu, G
studied a photoelectric simulation of a spacer layer with a refractive index of 1.4 and a thickness of approximately 4 μm to optimize light harvesting in 4T perovskite/silicon tandem solar cells
Anti-reflective film properties are one method to reduce incident light reflection loss and improve conversion performance
The use of anti-reflective polymer film with transparent materials with a suitable reflective index  and insulating layer properties is desirable to solve the optimal losses of the 4T tandem designs
Polydimethylsiloxane  appears to be an ideal material for the intermediate matching layer due to its properties as an anti-reflective film coating for solar cells and similar products [, ]
These properties include a suitable reflective index, high transparency in visible-near infrared  light, strong hydrophobicity, and simple solution processing
However, the PDMS film adheres strongly to materials with a high refractive index such as glass and crystal materials, making it challenging to remove each device from the 4T tandem cells
When considering the lifespan of a perovskite solar cell, it is preferable to design a system that incorporates both anti-reflective coatings and protective layers for the separated individual cells.
It is well-known that commercial silicon photovoltaic modules have a lifespan of over 20 years, during which their specified power output remains at 80% of their initial operation [28,29]
In contrast, the low device stability of PSC continues to be a significant commercialization hindrance [30,31]
Recently, outdoor testing of the encapsulated perovskite/silicon tandem lasted six months
Over only ten months of outdoor testing, PSCs encapsulated by lamination techniques maintained their initial effectiveness
Therefore, it is challenging to overcome this limitation and achieve commercial scale

Based on these findings, the inability to detach tandem solar cells containing PSC rendered this technique ineffective, and to our knowledge, no information on a detachable PSC for tandem applications had been previously published
et alWang, S
have only reported the flexible assembly and easily detachable stacking PSCs consisting of two individual half cells .
Therefore, a new concept for tandem solar cells called “clip-on” was proposed
This state-of-the-art enables the removal of PSCs with a short lifespan while firmly adhering two photovoltaic cells together

In this work, the encapsulated semitransparent perovskite solar cells  and unfiltered silicon heterojunction solar cells , as well as the air gap and clip-on sandwiched between the 4T perovskite/silicon tandems were successfully presented as shown in Fig

We used refractive index materials [commercial-PDMS  and silanol terminated polydimethylsiloxane ] as an intermediate matching layer in the 4T perovskite/silicon tandem cell to eliminate the air-spacer layer1
This work included a clip-on design for fabricating a four-contact tandem cell
The clip-on design was accomplished using PDMS-based materials sandwiched between polyvinyl chloride  films as a protective layer, which correspond to the configuration of PVC/IML/PVC
The removable device concept is based on a 4T perovskite/silicon heterojunction tandem solar cell with a clip-on pattern.
The preparation of commercial PDMS  films began with a mixture of elastomer base and curing agent in a predetermined proportion
The ratio of elastomer base to curing agent was adhered to following the manufacturer instructions, which specified a 10:1 ratio [, ]
For the characterization of the intermediate matching layer, the mixture was cast on soda lime glass  and spin-coated at a predetermined speed of 1500 rpm for 10 s
The intermediate
Selecting the material for the intermediate matching layer is the first crucial step in designing a successful clip-on tandem solar cell
The intermediate layer should possess the following properties: high transparency, high flexibility, low weight, hydrophobicity, anti-reflectiveness, and simple manufacturing processes [, ]
PDMS is ideally suited for these properties, particularly commercially available cross-linked PDMS
In addition, PDMS
Using PDMS as an intermediate matching layer and clip-on technology for the 4T perovskite/silicon heterojunction tandem cells improve tandem performance

The application of PDMS to create a clip-on design composed of PVC/IML/PVC between the top and the bottom cells achieved the highest efficiency of 23.49%, while the fully tandem configuration without a clip-on layer exhibited a PCE of 22.83%
The method has the potential to significantly increase the current density of silicon heterojunction
Kanyanee Sanglee: Writing – original draft, Methodology, Investigation, Formal analysis, Conceptualization
Siwakorn Sakunkaewkasem: Writing – original draft, Methodology, Investigation, Formal analysis, Conceptualization
Channarong Piromjit: Writing – review & editing, Methodology
Methawee Nukunudompanich: Writing – review & editing, Methodology
Pongsakorn Kanjanaboos: Conceptualization, Writing - review & editing
Surawut Chuangchote: Writing – review & editing, Supervision
Supakij
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
This contribution is partially supported by Energy Innovation Program, Technology Development Groups  project of the National Science and Technology Development Agency , Thailand .
This study reports the effective preparation of macro-encapsulated Cu–Ge alloy PCMs  for high-temperature thermal energy storage
The uniformly mixed Cu and Ge powders are spherulitized into millimeter/centimeter-sized balls, after which the core balls are coated with Al2O3 shells
The Cu–[email protected]2O3 macrocapsule with a cavity between the shell and core is successfully prepared after a two-step sintering process
The cavity formed by the pores and gaps among the powders can provide buffer spaces to support the volume expansion of the PCM during temperature increase and phase transition
The Cu–Ge alloy phase is synthesized in situ from Cu and Ge powders during the high-temperature sintering process
The melting-solidification cycling test demonstrates an excellent durability of the Cu–Ge capsules

The heat storage capacity of the capsules can be optimized by isostatic pressing to minimize excess cavities, and by adding sintering aids including MgO and SiO2 in the Al2O3 shells to increase the shell strength for achieving larger capsules with thinner shells

The macrocapsules present high heat storage density, especially for the Cu-40Ge capsules with a size of 9 [email protected] mm-100MPa, which show high values of 211 J/g and 719 MJ/m3 at a temperature region between 600 and 700 °C
The Cu-40Ge alloy is more suitable for high temperature thermal storage due to its better phase change properties and thermal cyclic durability.

Considering the fast pace of the development of the Photovoltaic  market and the installations in last two decades and also the increasing scarcity of resources for semiconductor materials, recycling waste PV modules including thin film is very important
Transparent conducting oxides  are extensively used as front contact electrodes in thin-film photovoltaic devices
The paper presents, the new strategies developed to extract TCO coated glass from thin film amorphous silicon PV end-of-life modules
The recycling of thin film PV modules is based on a very simple approach that includes chemical, thermal and mechanical treatments
Optimised solutions of 1 M NaOH and 1 M KOH were used to extract TCO coated glass
The feasibility of the processing steps was demonstrated on laboratory scale size module and the etching rate for P, I, and N-layers of amorphous silicon is also studied
The extracted TCO was identified as fluorine-doped tin oxide  using X-ray diffraction and UV–visible spectroscopy techniques
The laser scribed FTO glass was successfully extracted without damaging the properties of the material
The extracted FTO has very low resistivity and sheet resistance in the range of 10−4 Ω-cm and 11.74 Ω/sq
respectively, has uniform transmission throughout the measured film surface of 2 cm2 in the visible region having bandgap ∼3.8eV
The recycling cost and current market value of the recycled FTO are also estimated for all the installed capacities of amorphous silicon
Considering the TCO properties, extracted FTO has the potential for its reuse in the fabrication of new thin film PV modules and other optoelectronic device applications as well.
PET laminated photovoltaic modules present a high level of fire hazard, with varying levels of risk in complex external environments
This paper presents the experimental results of the ignition and combustion behavior of a PET laminated photovoltaic panel using the Fire Propagation Apparatus
The ignition time, heat release rate, combustion equivalent ratio, and total heat release were measured at different external heat flows and ventilation levels
The ignition time was determined as a function of the external radiant heat flow and the ventilation volume, respectively

The experimental results showed that the ignition time was sensitive to the change of external heat flow under different experimental conditions, but at lower external heat flow, the increase of ventilation had a great contribution to the shortening of the ignition time

The oxygen consumption method was used to determine the heat release rate under multiple boundary conditions, the value of which depends on the close coupling effect of external radiant heat flow and ventilation and is positively correlated with both
The immediate effect of boundary conditions on combustion efficiency was analyzed by equivalence ratios
For the total heat release, the external radiant heat flow directly plays a decisive role, but the ventilation volume can play a great role in promoting, especially under the low external heat flow.
WO3·2H2O film with porous structure was grown on indium tin oxide  glass by a simple constant current electrodeposition
The as-grown WO3·2H2O film shows a loose and porous structure, which is formed by the accumulation of large size nanoparticles
For comparison, amorphous WO3·xH2O film was prepared by constant voltage electrodeposition
Both the films prepared by CCE and CVE are hydrated oxides instead of simple oxides, which is proved by thermal analysis
A large optical modulation of 86.3% at 550 nm and a high coloration efficiency of 178.8 cm2 C−1 are achieved for the WO3·2H2O film
Additionally, the as-prepared film also shows a good cycling stability: the film exhibits an optical modulation of 75.6% after 500 cycles
Excellent electrochromic properties should be attributed to the porous structure of the WO3·2H2O film, which brings more electrochemical active sites for insertion and extraction of ions.
MgCl2-KCl-NaCl molten chloride salt is a promising candidate for thermal energy storage medium and heat transfer fluid for next-generation Concentrating Solar Power  plants
The main challenge has yet been the selection of economical yet corrosion-resistant structural materials to be used

Previous work by the authors has demonstrated that simple corrosion control strategies can mitigate corrosion effects, thereby allowing the use of classical stainless steels as structural materials in the hot part  of the CSP system
This study addresses the selection of cold tank materials, which have to withstand corrosion effects up to temperatures of 500 °C

Two cost-effective commercial types of steels, P91 and SS 304, were examined as candidates for structural materials, and controlled corrosion experiments were performed in molten MgCl2-KCl-NaCl salt at 500 °C for 1400 h
Before the exposure tests, the chloride salt was purified using a simple yet effective Mg-doping technique
The results show that the corrosion rates  of P91 samples are consistently low  for both macroscopic and microscopic analysis
The cheaper P91 steel outperforms the more expensive SS 304 in terms of corrosion resistance and also may prove to be beneficial in terms of mechanical properties and economics

Overall, the use of P91 as a cold tank structural material allows for significant cost reduction of the cold tank for chloride-TES system and enhances its competitiveness compared with commercial nitrate-TES.

Perovskite solar cells , the most promising nanostructured solar cells for large-scale production, have been fabricated with different types of electron and hole collectors to improve efficiency and stability
Incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency  is an important measurement to evaluate the optical/electrical behavior of the structure to modify the device structure

In this research, we have investigated how different mechanisms affect the IPCE spectra and the difference between short-circuit current density  recorded from the current density-voltage  and the IPCE curves of n-i-p PSCs
Results show that by removing the electron-transport layer  in a device with a compact PSK layer, the IPCE spectrum does not change and only a slight shift of interference peak position is observable
By removing the hole-transport layer , not only IPCE value drops substantially for all wavelengths, its shape  deforms significantly in the 500–800 nm wavelength range
In the case of cells with imperfect HTLs, only a slight change in this range  is observable

Utilizing different charge-transport and PSK materials, we have shown how significant the nonlinearity of the device's characteristics  with light intensity increases in the difference between Jsc value from J-V and integrated Jsc from IPCE curves

Selecting charge-collecting layers also directly affect interference peaks in IPCE spectra, for instance using TiO2 nanograss as ETL or CuIn0.75Ga0.25S2/carbon hole-collector instead of Spiro OMeTAD/Au hole-collector results in disappearing interference peaks.
